commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Put in a good word, perhaps?  (4)
2. Yogi, once  (4)(3)
3. Shiny little platters  (3)
4. It takes a long time to get this  (3)
5. Hearts or spades, but not diamonds  (4)(4)


EDIT
BEAR CUB
CDS
OLD
CARD GAME

Or as we used to say, 

Hold me closer, Tony Danza‚Ä¶
Here‚Äôs a thought: Maybe they can get Dr. Oz, Aaron Rodgers and Mayim Bialik to write guest columns until Ken Jennings gets the job permanently.

Welcome to the column Jo!
Hey is nobody going to point out this was a pangram? That‚Äôs quite an accomplishment for a Monday!

The theme was cute but otherwise unremarkable, and this was a fast solve even for a Monday, but besides smooth fill and a pangram there were some DISARMING entries like CURA√áAO UNKEMPT and SPARKPLUG.
Hi. The Sunday crossword disappears too early. By 6pm, I get Monday's.  Please leave more easily accessible for longer. Thanks.
That was fun! Thank you!
Too easy to even need to bother with the theme. Pretty straightforward puzzle.

Looks like the Sunday will end my streak. Gave it the full 24 hours, but can't work it out. My (potential) Naticks starting with my least certain:

oNO/VoILE
STEiG/NOiRE
MALAMuTE/REDBuDS
LeNA/eST
AbBY/UPbOW

I've reviewed everything else three times, but those are the only I'm not certain on, and I've tried a bunch of permutations for them, but no dice.
Like you, I too did a lot of sudoku. Now I do crosswords and (killer) sudoku.
Having a bit of a problem with spark plug as devise for starting an engine.
I gotta remember AREPA‚Ä¶ got roti and naan in my memory, but AREPA still eludes me.  Never eaten one!  Maybe I‚Äôll make them myself, then I won‚Äôt forget.  They look tasty.

5A: "Factory-made" butter is also produced by churning, so [Old-fashioned] doesn't seem to be needed in the clue.

Any current dairy folk care to comment?
Why do you change the puzzle so early?

Blue pen baby
Wordplay lady
Puzzler for the band
Pretty bright
Quiet smile
You're making your crossword plans

Fill machine-uh
You must have seen her
Solving 'cross the land
And now she's grid-deep
Always with me
Many answers in her hands

But oh how it feels so real
Trying themes with no one near
Only you and you can hear me
When I say softly, slowly

Hold me closer, bright-eyed solver
Count the blank squares in the crossword
Lay me down in sheets of newsprint
You had a puzzling day today

(It'll be Taupin the charts.)
So fun!
Horrible yet again...   The dmv does not give you an eye exam, that would be an optometrist....  A  spark plug does not 'start and engine'.

I LOVE a fun puzzle & this fit the bill! The theme was good. I knew those songs - yay!
We used to have a combination eye/sign exam at the NCDMV. Now they just test your eyes. How else are they supposed to know if you need glasses to drive? ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
Thank you, Peter! Have a wonderful Monday, y‚Äôall!

I finally got one!

Monday is the hardest day of the week, right?

Stonelets, as it were.
I knew the songs, but can't say as any of them qualify as earworms for me.

A smooth Monday puzzle, thanks, Peter.

I was not familiar with the Billy Joel/Ray Charles collaboration. Billy idolized Ray. It's got a nice bluesy, r and b feel to it. (Big surprise.) Kind of nice on a snowy Sunday evening. https://youtu.be/XUNOmN3YVL0?si=oSwEiz0wFq7pOBcB

The SW corner was somewhat challenging for me. I thought Bruins were from Canada, so I was not quick to come up with UCLA (over the years l've learned the names of some of your sport teams and colleges, but I just can't see me ever remembering - nor caring about, really - which team comes from where).

I didn't know beaing in LALA land meant daydreaming.

I also had gOAd before I changed it to COAX. It took me a while to see thay mistake, because the two letters in the middle were correct, and the ones on the ends crossed with stumpers. You peeps take an EYE EXAM at the DMV?! On that topic:

The differences between our countries are countless. Over here we don't have a specialized DMV. Your driver's license is issued by the county administration - at the middle tier of our three tier, autonomous local government - after taking a course at a licensed driving school, passing a state-organized theoretical and practical exam, and having your health and eyesight  checked by a licensed doctor. The official at the county office simply checks your paperwork. 

Also, isn't saying "UPC code" akin to "ATM machine"?
SMILEYS is not an appropriate pluralization of SMILEY. That would be SMILIES

I‚Äôd like to see ‚ÄúQ-Tip‚Äù clued as something to do with ‚ÄúA Tribe Called Quest.‚Äù 

If crossword setters think all of us know Elton John and John Mellencamp songs, I think they could throw in some famous rappers rather than dropping store brands as the clueing.
I could not UNSEE Bside for way too long.
A GEM is also a LITTLE ROCK üíé

I know it's a Monday, but I'm a relative NEWBIE (five months), so I'm glad I got this one done WITHOUTANYLOOKUPS.

By the way, Jo, could a nine-letter word for a ‚Äúhand-held blues instrument" be a SAXOPHONE?

A Goldilocks Monday for me. Halfway between my average and best times.

As one who has worked on thousands of gasoline engines in my lifetime, I cannot go without saying that 35D could have been clued with much more accuracy.

I was also surprised to see how many downs were completely filled as I blasted through the across answers.

High QUALITY puzzle for a Monday, especially with the panagram. The song that comes to mind for me is Little Talks by Of Monsters and Men https://youtu.be/ghb6eDopW8I?si=XBwybiqE-fEMuSid Another favorite is Little Lion Man by Mumford & Sons https://youtu.be/5qDusitZ9EU?si=mHPG4z29-7e9u_3t One more song I thought of was also a John Mellencamp one - Pink Houses because of the lyrics. There is a Little Pink House around the corner from me with a placard on the front identifying it as such. I think they Air B&B it. It is very charming. One might even be delighted by it ü§£ And YURI led me to think about the astronauts who just returned from the ISS early. I am truly lucky to live where I can regularly experience launch and re-entry of space vehicles on a regular basis. Thank you for this GEM, Peter.

I would have had an easier time had I known the three letter singer or how to misspell normalise. 

SPARKPLUGS do not start an engine. They keep it running. 

The ALGORE clue was delightful (sorry Andrzej) 

Overall a very nice puzzle. A tad chewy as I could not recall any of the songs and didn‚Äôt know DOCTER. It came together pretty easily in any case.

Okay, emus.  If you really want to get rid of off topic posts, then here's your chance.  What I'm about to post is as utterly absurd as it is potentially brilliant.

I'm sure a lot of us here are older Americans.  I mean, we're working *crossword puzzles*, so .... duh.

I have found, I can't believe I'm saying this, but I have found that when I'm barefoot or in socks, I have *much* more stability if I splay my toes (again, total disbelief on my part as I hate talking about feet or toes) and pretend I'm gripping the floor with my footses (see what I mean?). 

It's astonishing how much stability one can feel from the toes if you really focus on it.  They are astonishingly powerful in providing just the tiny amount of force needed to stabilize an absurdly old and out of shape body.

I think the number of years of wearing shoes has numbed our appreciation of the value of those ten little piggies.

So, irrespective of any clue or answer in this puzzle, I'm wondering if everyone other than me missed the memo, or if I've discovered a silver bullet concerning elderly balance.

This is a PSA concerning the danger of falls of elderly people.
Lots of time for Ilhan as a rep and I don‚Äôt even live in the country.
Tiny Dancer came out in 1971 not 1972 !

I got the TINY DANCER album - Madman Across the Water -  for my birthday many year ago. For a long time it seemed that my sisters and I were the only ones who liked it, it wasn't popular at all. Now everyone seems to know it.

I didn't know the rest of the music or the president but the rest was straightforward enough.

OMG

I FOUND MY MISTAKE

It was the the 25 square.

I had GAg/gETLISTS

A GAG is definitely an hilarious thing. And a GETLIST sounds like something a promoter would procure. Think, "Here's the list of artists I got for the concert."

Of course, the correct answer is GAS/SETLISTS
A fun one. Clue for SPARKPLUG could have used a bit more juice. This morning's TIL is that there is a Big Rock, Arkansas: https://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/entries/big-rock-5492/
Fun Monday!  Clever theme, enjoyable fill.
So many long, interesting, and filled-with-connection back-and-forths in the comments.  I love this forum!

LITTLECREATURES could have been one.

SPARKPLUG definitely incorrectly clued.

As I filled in this grid, it seemed that every time I turned a corner I ran into answers that felt interesting ‚Äì words that were common enough to be in most everyone‚Äôs vocabulary, but not used so much that they‚Äôve become dull.

Words like CHURN, GIRTH, UNKEMPT, TRYOUTS, DISARMS, and NORMALIZE.  

The star answers, IMO, were the three colorful song titles, but these other answers backed those star answers up, like backup singers behind a star singer, who help make the star shine.

The result, for me, was a puzzle that was more than what we often get ‚Äì a smashing theme surrounded by forgettable answers.  No, the entire grid had an undercurrent of interest and beauty, and when I finished it, I thought, ‚ÄúNow that‚Äôs a high-quality puzzle.‚Äù  And I felt good inside and out.

I‚Äôve had the same reaction to your other puzzles, Peter, and am very grateful for your work.  Thank you!

Fun puzzle. Bit of a workout but everything fell together from working the crosses. And had to stop and ponder for a moment when I was almost done before I caught on to the theme. That's always a nice touch. And... an appropriate puzzle find for today. A Monday from January 20, 2014 by Elizabeth C. Gorski. Theme answers in that one: LINCOLNMEMORIAL CIVILRIGHTS IHAVEADREAM WEAREFREEATLAST and MLKJR Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/20/2014&g=38&d=A ...

Didn't recognize SZA or DOCTER, but that's what the crossings provided. 

Pretty mimimal (TINY, SMALL, BABY?) theme, but a solid enough Monday puzzle, and a pangram to boot.

What a thoroughly delightful, yet tricky Monday puzzle! I loved the wordplay of the theme - LITTLE ROCK. üòÑ And even the trickiness was fun. I had ‚ÄúSia‚Äù for 41A (though I don‚Äôt know either her music or SZA‚Äôa for that matter), had ‚Äúcold‚Äù for 62D, and had ‚Äúwaist‚Äù and ‚Äútorso‚Äù before GIRTH for 53A! Lots of interesting words in this one!

There are too many Springfields in America.
It‚Äôs like a virus.
Having to guess which one made me sic(k, emus?).
Sure, eventually I caught (on to) what was going around.
But it didn‚Äôt even rhyme, which is all that matters - not if your Springfields was ill.
Clued differently, the answer could‚Äôve been BLUES HARP as well as HARMONICA.  Anyhoo, this was a welcome Monday after my Friday, Saturday, and Sunday tribulations!
I‚Äôm new to crosswords, but I‚Äôm getting better with each puzzle! Finished this one in 15 minutes 30 seconds relying a bit on autocheck. Is that frowned upon??

Arrgh.  I'm just here to find out what goes in square 41.  Here we have a True Natick.  

Nice Monday puzzle (even if often out of my wheelhouse.)

In case a road trip takes you across the country using I-40, a stop in LITTLE ROCK is worthwhile.  Heifer International's headquarters--right next to the Clinton Presidential Library--is educational and intriguing.  Just down the street, the Central Library has significant displays--for instance, re the detention camps where Japanese citizens were incarcerated despite their Constitutional rights.  The Presidential Library (one of several 'green' buildings) brings in important artists (Chihuly, for example, and amazing Lego  constructions).  Cross the Arkansas River on the old railroad bridge if you feel like it.  Tucked a couple of blocks away, a Historic Arkansas Museum is worth a visit.  As the state was part of The Louisiana Purchase, the French influence and heritage is evident (as long as you ignore the actual French pronunciation for, say, Petit Jean Mountain/River  or anything named for  Aux Arc.)

For submission to the editors suggestion box:

In paragraph two, today's Wordplay author states, "I know nothing about sports..."  I often wonder if this is true, or mostly true, about constructors and their editors in general.  

There's plenty I know nothing about, but sports is not one of them.  So I find it curious that sports terms are so often mangled or down right mistaken in sports related clues / answers. 

Yesterday we had the bewildering assertion that a basketball ref would issue a traveling violation warning.  No.  Never.

And then just the day before a tennis shot described as a DINK instead of a drop (shot).  What?  

And just prior to that, the assertion that a layup could be somehow described as LAID IN.

I know this has been defended as "it's okay because it's a crossword."  As a sports person and sports fan, sports should be accurately represented, not twisted to suit the constructors fill, IMO.
Welcome, Jo!
Isn't UPC an initialism for Universal Product Code?

This felt like a special Monday to me. Spark plug issues aside, I thought the puzzle was fresh, fun, and cleverly constructed in a way that elevated my experience‚Äîpangram and all. Add to that the entertaining and relatable debut of guest columnist Jo Firestone, unexpected trivia in the constructor notes, and a lively comments section. Thank you one and all! This doesn‚Äôt happen every day. For a moment I was dragged out of my mundane workaholic stupor.

Regarding 42 D,

If you look closely at the recent "gift", it says "Noble Peece Pryze".

That Machado is *such* a joker.
If anyone wants a bit more of a challenge (in a non-archive puzzle), Erik Agard has a LITTLE ROCK over at The New Yorker.
Fun and breezy, extra cheesy! Thanks Peter!

The thrill I feel when I check to see if a puzzle includes every letter of the alphabet is ridiculous, and my heart falls when the fill fails to fulfill my hope. It's actually pretty rare to see a 15x15 pangram! So thanks and congratulations to Peter Gorman, for a lovely puzzle and a pangram! 

Enjoying the quality of the puzzle's clues and entries slowed me down from my normal Monday pace! Loved to see SZA and Rep. Omar in the puzzle! I also chuckled at "Sporting blade" as the clue for the ultra-common EPEE, even though Jo called it out in the story without an Errol Flynn hat tip to the wit.

Nice, very fun puzzle! I may be nitpicking, but SPARKPLUGs aren‚Äôt technically really a ‚Äúdevice to start an engine.‚Äù They fire continuously as an engine runs to trigger combustion, but the device that actually starts most modern engines is a starter motor initiated by the battery. Spark plugs are involved, sure‚Ä¶ but only as much as any other component of the engine necessary to keep it running, such as a carburetor, fuel pump, etc.

A fun thing I sometimes attempt with early week puzzles is to create a frame of letters by filling all the outside letters  of the grid.  Surprising how often I fail even with the Mondays. Today was one of those rare triumphs.

Thank you, Peter, for a "little" melodic start to the week -- I enjoyed this grid. Welcome, Jo -- your commentary brought delightful pre-gaming levity!

Happy MLK Jr Day, everyone. He would have been 97 years old and, no doubt, outraged by what is happening over 57 years since his death. His words: "In the end, we will remember not the words of our enemies, but the silence of our friends," once again, ring so true. I'm grateful for our little global community here where we must stay vocal and strong in the name of peace and justice. ‚öñÔ∏è‚òÆÔ∏èü´∂üèº
Aw, Jo's really cute. I hope she had fun!

I'm back to doing crosswords regularly after a long hiatus studying for exams! 
Today's was fun and satisfying, and I didn't need to google anything or use AutoCheck -- both big wins for me today. 
Happy MLK day everyone.
So close to beating my Monday challenge of filling it out sequentially with no skips or mistakes, but I was undone by my own hubris in jumping at SMILIES rather than SMILEYS Better luck next time :/

To all the SPARKPLUG quibblers, I offer these words of wisdom from the inimitable Bruce Springsteen:

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt start a fire without a spark.‚Äù üî• 

And I don‚Äôt think he meant just Hemis.
And now I have some earworms for today!

Here‚Äôs my poem made from today‚Äôs puzzle:

a/ the coffee rings
bronze shadow things
of you of coffee measurement of
in-progress projects shifted
to spent
d/ lines of code
maps for a prize
a tooth a pulse a soul
and a fork at the spot
where the fork is
at the a/ side

Did Eric Hougland fix the puzzle voting link? Many I didn‚Äôt get to if someone else called it or I ran out of steam. I love every NYT puzzle: Sunday ‚ÄúTwo for One‚Äù February 2d by Derick Niederman https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/01/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-02-02.html?unlocked_article_code=1.t04._ax8.6fwNsyexm1ox&smid=url-share Sunday Adam Wagner 3-22-25 ‚ÄúRainbow Connection‚Äù https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/01/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-03-02.html Sunday May 4th by Brandon Koppy ‚ÄúForce Play‚Äù https://www.nytimes.com/2025/05/03/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-05-04.html Sunday June 1, 2025 ny Sam Brody ‚ÄúMaking Arrangements‚Äù https://www.nytimes.com/2025/05/31/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-06-01.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare Tuesday June 24, 2025 Ingrid Steffensen ‚ÄúRoyal Domain‚Äù https://www.nytimes.com/2025/06/23/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-06-24.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare Wednesday May 7, 2025 Tom McCoy ‚ÄúTheater Boxes‚Äù https://www.nytimes.com/2025/05/06/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-05-07.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share& Thursday 10-2-25 Aidan Deshong ‚ÄúOut of the Park‚Äù https://www.nytimes.com/2025/10/01/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-10-02.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare Thursday October 15 Kareem Hayas ‚ÄúHow Whiskey Might Be Served‚Äù The No ICE puzzle. Good one! https://www.nytimes.com/2025/10/15/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-10-16.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare
Did there used to be a monthly crossword puzzle or am I just imagining that?

A good theme to start the week. I especially like the oxymoronic BABY GRAND. Has there been an oxymoron themed puzzle? There must have been but I can‚Äôt recall. 

The revealer puts me in mind of Marilyn Monroe and Jane Russell singing ‚ÄúA Little Girl from Little Rock‚Äù in ‚ÄúGentlemen Prefer Blondes‚Äù. Talk about spark plugs.

What a nice, fun puzzle for a Monday.

Thank you, Creator.

And Cheers! to my fellow humans of Earth. Remember the old saying, 'this too shall pass'.

I'm straight up on team spark plug quibble. Spark plug. It's a device for making the engine go integral to continued operation. "Starting" is a discrete, one time event where the engine goes from off to on (from not started to running). Any semantic gymnastics to explain it away either displays a fundamental lack of understanding as to how it works and what it does..or is disingenuous.

Don't get me wrong. I thought this puzzle was great. Just that particular cluing was sloppy. 

I believe clues should come with an "a-ha" understanding (pun or play on words) or something that is factual (and perhaps obscure) and maybe you learn something. 

What a spark plug does and how it works is not technical arcana.

One more puzzle find. A Tuesday from January 7, 2003 by Peter Gordon. Five 15 letter grid spanning entries in that one, including a triple stack in the very middle. Those answers: PANAMACANALARAB RAMADACATAMARAN ALABAMAMAHARAJA BANANARAMASAGAS BABAWAWASAVATAR Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/7/2003&g=31&d=A ...

Last night, we had dinner at home with my husband and one of his daughters (fajitas! yum!!), my husband was saying something about Yale (not a typical area of discussion for us) and I suddenly and excitedly blurted out, "Do you know who Yale's benefactor was? Elihu Yale! And do you know what they apparently call Yale students? That's right, Elis!!!" 

It all came tumbling out quickly. If I could have, I'd have slo-mo dived to put them back in but it was too late. 

You should have seen the oh so very hilarious side-eye look my husband was giving me, which just cracked me up. It was so funny! His daughter is used to our antics and just laughed and correctly guessed this was random crossword info on my part! Ha!  What a joy I must be to have around! üòÜ

Nice, quick puzzle! Happy to see Minnesota represented, as well as some great tunes! 

Life's been a bit crazy but I'm trying to limit my doom scrolling activities... and as my acupuncturist reminded me: look for the light and be the light.

Thanks for adding a new one to the list of TLA tautologies:
GPS System, ATM Machine, and now UPC Code.

Because Monday is so easy, I challenge myself to finish in under 10 minutes. Today, I made it by 2 seconds. 
I tried doing just across or just down. I haven't done that yet.

Do animated movies really have directors? I suppose somebody has to work with the voice actors, but is that really directing? Show runner, maybe. Didn't know Mr DOCTER, at any rate, although I did see "Up" and enjoyed it very much.

One more late puzzle find. A Sunday from November 10, 1996 by R. Hamel with the title: "To a T". Some theme answers in that one: TWICETOLDTALES TRAVELEDTHROUGHTIME TAKESTOTASK TICTACTOE TENTIMESTEN TORATORATORA TONYTHETIGER TIPTOETHRUTHETULIPS TOTELLTHETRUTH Again, don't recall another puzzle quite like that. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/10/1996&g=15&d=D ...
Universal bar code code ;)

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[People often manage with them, in brief]  (4)
[It might come with a shell]  (3)


MBAS
OAR

@Lewis
My favorites from last week were both from Adam Aaronson: 
1. [Ones running along a road] (9)
2. [Dough at a taquer√≠a] (5)

SIDEWALKS 
PESOS

@Lewis
But some of us think that getting OLD happened very, very fast!

@Steve L

I always thought it was "Hold me closer, twiny cancer..."

@Francis
Whoof. That's some dark turn!

@SBK

I'm a joy to be around.

@Steve L
There was a "Barney Miller" episode with a Russian musician who loves America and wants to defect. He quotes the line from the song in a heavy Slavic accent. A TV moment that stuck with me. The episode is "Asylum." Could not find it on YT.
@Steve L Count the head lice on the highway!

@Steve L

I came here to say the same.  I think it's the funniest mis-heard lyric ever, surpassing even "There's a bathroom on the right." from Bad Moon Rising.  I always picture someone fueld with liquid courage at a karaoke bar discovering their mistake live on stage.  Or not.

@Steve L

Aaron Rodgers does have a lot of free time coming up,  and probably more in the foreseeable future. I would be happy to see Mayim writing anything, she is a treasure, and would probably be a good crossword commentator.

@lucky13

DON'T look at the NFL scores tonight.  Just ignore the rest of the season and assume everything went perfectly for the Bears.

One of the few games I really cared about.  I should have known how it would go.

Much like the World Series trauma.

@lucky13

I‚Äôm a Packer fan so it‚Äôs hard to root for the Bears. But gotta say they have a plucky team and almost pulled it off yesterday too so I do feel bad for them. I would have loved to see a Steelers/Bears Super Bowl with Aaron Rodgers against them (although as a Cincinnatian it‚Äôs also hard to root for the Steelers).

@SP

I guess you are. Doesn‚Äôt matter much to me.
@SP Yes, I noticed this too, but you beat me to mentioning it. Congrats to Peter Gorman,  and to you.

@DF On the weekend, the next day's puzzle is avaliable at 6 (not 10) pm eastern the night before. So starting Sat. 6 pm,  you have a full 24 hrs to work on the Sunday puzzle before Monday's is posted.

@DF,

If it wasn‚Äôt clear from what @Steve L said, you can still work on the Sunday puzzle past 6 pm, up until midnight local time (possibly later) if you‚Äôre trying to maintain a streak.

Dave K.,
I believe you've been solving for more than a few weeks now, so I don't think you should ever need the theme to solve a Monday puzzle. You might enjoy trying to figure out the revealer from the theme before getting to it. It's something to add to a straightforward easy puzzle.

@Steven M.  All those are consistent with my solve‚Ä¶ likely something else‚Ä¶ if you haven‚Äôt already, try going to line-by-line clue mode.  Sometimes that way of looking at stuff triggers an ah-ha moment for me.

@Steven M.
Check the rest of the fill again - those 5 crossings look correct to me.

@Steven M.

I had SniTS rather than SPATS.

@Steven M. Are you solving on the NYT app? Even if it takes you till, e.g., Wednesday to solve a Sunday puzzle, as long as you put off doing the Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday puzzles until you complete the Sunday one, your streak will be counted. It‚Äôs not like Wordle where a puzzle is on for only 24 hours, and then your streak is considered broken. Also, once you‚Äôve completed the Sunday one, make sure to then do the Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday puzzles in that order. Speaking from bitter experience üòÑ
(note: they‚Äôve just lately added a feature to allow solving of past Wordle puzzles, and while it will add to your solve count and percentage stats, the 24-hr. limit for maintaining streaks still counts).
@Joey Okay, I'll keep trying

@Steven M.

The odds against us increase factorially when the number of uncertain squares increase.

Two is barely possible to overcome.  Three is impossible.

Unless of course you can reduce the number of possible letters for each.

@Steven M.

Let us know when you find it.  We're all curious.

@Francis

I just found it. It was the 25 crossing. I had GAg/gETLISTS

@Steven M.

Good for you!

@Francis

Actually, I'm stupid.  The odds against us are raised to the 26th power for every square we don't know.

Way bigger than factorials, for a while at least.

Right, Andrzej?
@Grumpy 184 days

@Francis

I see Andrzej didn‚Äôt get back to you. 

One blank square has 26 possibilities
Two blank squares have 26x26 = 26 squared
Three squares have 26x26x26 = 26 cubed

So it‚Äôs 26 to the power of however many blank squares you have. (Wish I could do superscripts)

userLocation: Amdmt 25-not just a footnote any more
commentBody:
@Lynn
26 ^ (however many blank squares you have)
"Hand crank" fits, but it doesn't cross.

Agree. Not a great clue. Saying a spark plug is used to start a car is like saying gasoline is used to start a car. A better clue would be "Device used to KEEP a car running" (still not crazy about calling a spark plug a "device").
@Philly Carey - The spark plug sparks the engine.

@Philly Carey
It is a device used in starting an engine.  It doesn't need to be the only device, or used to start every kind of engine, to be a correct clue.

@Steve L
Surprised to hear that an e-car needs no oil. Given that it consists of metal parts closely engaged in 1000s of repetitive motions under all kinds of weather and in all kinds of terrain, how can it not need lubrication?

@SBK

I'm as surprised as you are.

@Steve L we have both a Tesla and a Rivian. We will probably replace the Tesla with an EV truck because we miss having a truck. The charging infrastructure has increased significantly in my area of the country, so road trips are much easier now. And the Rivian gets amazing mileage (~400 miles in Conserve mode). My husband still has his classic vehicles for cruising and off roading, but I love our EVs. We bought a house that had solar panels already, so we basically charge our vehicles for free at home.

@Francis

It's the same reason your refrigerator or your AC unit doesn't need an oil change, I guess.

@Andrzej

We live in a mixed housing development, containing some condo apartment buildings, some rental apartment buildings, and some rowhouse condos with garages and driveways.  We live in the last type.  

One of the apartment buildings has a parking lot and garage with chargers in every space, but those spaces are assigned to specific people.  Of course, the vast majority don't need the chargers, so their installation was a complete waste.  Another building has a smattering of them, but I assume enough to assign those spaces on the basis of need.  

There are two public chargers in one of the lots that are available to everyone. When I first bought the car, I decided to try one out and see how it worked.  It turns out it was priced prohibitively expensively, and not especially fast.  

So I started plugging the car into my regular outdoor outlet while mulling over my next step.  I knew I would probably install a charger in my garage, but it cost about $2000 to buy and pay an electrician to install.

It took about three days to fully charge the car using a regular outlet.  Although it was sufficient for my normal usage most of the time, I gave in and bought the charger.

People told me that the electricity I used charging at home would barely cause my power bill to go up, and they were right.  And it gives a full charge overnight.

On the road, charging is not free, although a couple of hotels we stayed at did have it available free as an amenity.
Had a AREPA on Friday. Very tasty!
An AREPA. The Classic Reina Arepa. https://www.classicarepastogo.com/ny31/menu.php
@sonnel An AREPA has become my favorite ballpark food at Nationals Park in the last two years.
@sonnel https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/4d9ugb?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

@sonnel
They are tasty but I wouldn't call them flatbreads since they are filled. Maybe not always?

RozzieGrandma,
Re: flatbreads
See also pita (a.k.a khubz).

.

@RozzieGrandma

I wouldn't have described them as flatbreads, either, but rather corncakes or South American pancakes, but I guess they are.

@RozzieGrandma

I had the same thought, but then there are other flatbreads that can be stuffed. (Paratha was the one that came immediately to mind.) I guess for me the difference is I've never had an arepa that *wasn't* stuffed!

Grumpy,
Three and four in your cite are in addition to, not replacements for, one and two. The issue is not whether all factory butter is made by churning, but whether any of it is. And it is.

@Barry Ancona
Your point about modern butter making may be true but I still like the clue. It brings to mind the image of an old wooden butter churn.
I think CHURN suggests the old-fashioned one to everyone except commercial butter makers. I would have seen it without the words in the clue.

@Barry Ancona Well, having gone on a few grade school outings to ‚Äúhistorical‚Äú sites, I‚Äôm very familiar with what an old-fashioned butter churn is. I even spent a few minutes working one ‚Äî and boy, is it hard work! Perhaps some machines in industrial dairy works are actually called ‚Äúchurns,‚Äù and perhaps they aren‚Äôt. But the clue had resonance for me, and it was nostalgic to see  the noun form of the word.

Brad,
You would have seen the noun form of the word without "old-fashioned" in the clue.

Are you messing with us? If someone else posted what you just did, you would reply, "An old-fashioned butter maker is a CHURN. The clue is fine."

@Ben Thomas

tradition of dead-tree newspaper editions to have an early printing on Saturdays and Sundays

@Francis

Well, not all newspapers did that. 
And often it was just an early print run for the non-news feature sections. A newspaper would print the Sunday features (comics, puzzles, weekend magazine, ads) ahead of time and even deliver it on Saturday.
Early printing also helps reduce the expense of weekend over-time pay, and may even be part of union contracts.

The NYT keeps to the print traditions for the crossword puzzle. The newer online-only games don't care so much.

@Linda Jo

The tiny newspaper I worked for published half of the Sunday (but not the Saturday) in advance.

@Francis
I remember when Reagan was Governor and sent the National Guard to Berkeley to stop the anti war demonstrations, I looked down  out of the window of my fourth floor apartment and was shocked to see a personnel carrier parked on the street below.

My roommate had come home the day before with her eyes streaming from teargas that was lingering in the drugstore  across the street.

A lot of people were injured and one person died from bird shot fired into the demonstrators, which somehow hit him while he was on the top of a building, watching, and someone must have aimed it at him, an outlined target.  

It was a nightmarish time, joining the marches and candlelight vigils. The National Guardsmen were just boys who didn't want to be there and embarrassed when girls slid long stem roses down the barrels of their rifles.

It was nothing, just child's play, compared to the mass chaos we are seeing on the news from Minneapolis.  Be safe, Francis, we need you alive.

@Hanson

But on that topic, a large amount of my taxes have gone to things that I think were misappropriated.  Does that come into the discussion somewhere?

For example, 28 billion dollars of tax money from people like me are going to support 3000 ice agents, who are wreaking havoc on my state.  They are rounding up the least violent people, the mostly peaceful people, and many US citizens who happen to be the wrong color, and sending them in chains to who-knows-where.

I would consider that "misappropriated".

So do I get a say on complaints about "misappropriated taxes"?

@Andrzej
It is difficult to watch this, given my age.  Will I live long enough to look back on these dark days?

I remember my utter shock and horror when I learned about the 'relocation' of Japanese citizens after the Pearl Harbor attack and declaration of war.  It was never mentioned in our American History class (which barely got past WWI before the end of the year.)  I was so ashamed of FDR and the legislators...  

And now we have an even worse period of lawless, unConstitutional mass mistreatment!

@dutchiris I was at Berkely at the time when Reagan closed the campus and a bunch of us spent the night on the campus so that we could go from there the next morning to picket the draft board and the induction center.  I also remember the People's Park protest when two protesters were killed, one with bird shot and another with buck shot.  The University needed to protect its property rights.  
Like Mean Old Lady, I hope to live long enough to get through this.

@Francis This was the first song I thought of. On a side note, I got to meet Stephen Stills when I was 5, as my dad was his banker in Miami. Pretty cool! Do know that millions of us stand with all of you!

@dutchiris
I went to sleep thinking about the marches and demonstrations of the '60s, and they weren't child's play.  They were peaceful until the county sheriffs showed up, big guys in uniform who started shoving people, until things started to fall apart, then used tear gas, clubs, and arrested people. Added to the tumoil there were paid agitators and just people who  hurled rocks to break windows,  taunted the big guys in blue, thrilled by the idea of starting a riot.  

Once, there was a sweep of our downtown area (Berkeley is pretty small), when they herded scores into a parking lot,some of whom were on meds, diabetics, students, faculty, women who were shopping, business men on their way to meetings, then loaded them on buses and drove them to an out-of-town jail, where they kept them overnight, all to crush support for the demonstrations. . 

One morning I saw a mob of cops on the street below our office window drag a young man to the sidewalk and form a screen to hide that they were beating him. I screamed that I could see what they were doing.  They didn't care.

It was more of a dress rehearsal for what we have now than child's play.  In the end, it didn't work then and it must not work now.

commentBody:
@Warren
Late for the party but very happy to see the Be Good Tanyas. Absolutely excellent music.

@Andrzej

I don't suppose you'll be surprised to hear me say that your system seems more complete and more logical.

It's a very trivial eye exam.  Not remotely like what you get in an  optometrist office.

You look in a screen, and they test your ability to pick something out a scene that is, I assume, modified to test peripheral and maybe color vision.  It was never hard for me, except the last time, when for a second I couldn't see some letters embedded in a scene.  

I knew at that moment that the most likely reason for me to lose my driving privileges was because of eyesight, though I've been blessed with very good eyesight my whole life.

Others here I'm sure are much more capable of explaining the DMV eye test than I am.

I was genuinely happy to finally remember AREPA, and on that note, I would like to thank the NYT for inspiring my wife and I to have one of the best meals during our 2025 English holiday. We visited Cambridge, among other places. A square in the cenyer of town was full of food trucks. One of them flew the Venezuelan flag, which caught our attention. They served arepas! "It's the thing from the crosswords!" I called out to my wife, "we have to try it!" The lovely owners served us delicious flatbreads stuffed with some of the best meat stew I've ever had in my life - juicy, tender, aromatic. Wow! I will never forget AREPA after that experience. If you're ever in Cambridge, check out "ManaCambs - Arepas": https://maps.app.goo.gl/URTd7LqgkBQUBdxM9

@Francis

Thanks! Would you believe it - over here we think only professionals are qualified to test people's eyesight and general medical considerations of driving. Does that make us communists?

@SBK

You are right, and yet I could see GOAD actually being the answer, though it be a contentious one.

@Andrzej

look...

he has no trouble calling people lovely.

but delightful?

never!

@Matt

They really were lovely though - what can I do?

@Francis

i think protactinium might get the nod...

@Andrzej when I got my driver‚Äôs license in London some decades ago all you were required to do with respect to your eyesight was  read a number plate on some parked car on the way to your car to start the driving test. The theoretical component involved the examiner asking a few questions after the driving itself was done. 

My kids who passed in Germany had at the time  of the exam encyclopedic knowledge of all aspects of driving, day/night city/autobahn as well as having done a first aid course. Still being driven by them at first was somewhat terrifying üòÄ

@Andrzej my husband works for UCLA Health. UCLA is very popular and receives the most applicants year after year for the entire country. California universities in general receive more applicants because the UC system has a single application for all of its campuses and they don‚Äôt consider test scores (like the SAT OR ACT). I personally attended UC Riverside. https://www.collegetransitions.com/blog/most-applied-to-colleges/

@Jacqui J

Seconded.  UCLA has a really good reputation.  I would have been proud to have graduated from there.
@Andrzej I wish that were so in the US! Unfortunately the process varies widely from state to state, and seems that most learn either through osmosis or GTA. Lucky you! (and in so many other ways)

@John Carson

Thanks!  

It's really hard for youngsters to understand how deeply frightening falling becomes.  

My wife had a very gentle fall on a mat while training our dog, and she's been getting up with groans for about three days now.

It probably would have killed me.

I'm going to try to find some instructions on "how to fall" for old fŒ±rts like myself.

Good morning Francis,

Not sure about your toe theory but I am going to check it out.  

Regarding fear of falling, stay away from Crocs.  Years ago while wearing them, I walked quickly through my garage that had a painted floor.  One foot hit a small puddle and I may as well have been on ice skates.  Smashed my knee without any chance of bracing against the fall.

The damage done to my knee, tibia, and related parts, along with the world's worst ortho surgeon, has been life changing.

Anyway, sorry for the off topic, but this is my PSA.  Crocs at minimum should come with a strong warning.

@Francis

i was at a zen retreat years ago and the roshi (master) challenged us to meditate into our toes, thinking of nothing else.

not orthodox zen practice by any means.

but a number of us reported a different sort of gait "sharpness" for at least a day or two afterwards.

@Francis

Yes.
Amen.

I fell almost two years ago
trying to step over a puppy gate.

Crushed my ankle.
nine breaks, two titanium plates and eleven screws
later, I lived in a chair, in constant pain for months.

Ankle is good enough to walk on,
but my toes on that foot never recovered
from being immobilized for so long.

They're so very stiff.
And as a result, my balance 
and consequent fear of falling again is *so* real.

Not because of the crushed ankle.
My toes!

So I've started walking barefoot every day.

And I bought a pair of "barefoot shoes."
They're incredible.

@Matt

I am so impressed that you were a part of a zen retreat.  But not, as I ponder your posts, all that surprised.

I can absolutely believe that.  Even to think of your toes while one is walking almost immediately results in a great sense of stability and well-being.  

I am hoping to use that on Artist's Point in Grand Marais once the ice melts.  Each spring my confidence dims a bit.

I think I'm going to start a cult.  The Ape Toed.

Anybody want to suggest a logo and You Tube channel name?

@Kathryn

Oh my God!

I'm so sorry to hear about your life-altering fall.  I hope you recover as much as is humanly possible.

What a poignant and appropriate reply!

@CCNY

I hope you are fall-free from this time on.

I, too, step over puppy gates, at the top of some stairs.  I feel quite vulnerable when I do.  I don't think my wife who is six/seven years younger feels it quite like I do.

At one time, when I was a puppy, I used to go down a flight of at least 10 steps only touching one on the way down.

Time always wins.

@Marlene

I'm so sorry.  Pain seems like such an unnecessary reaction when there's nothing we can do to relieve it.  If we could just tell our minds "it's okay, I'm doing all I can".

It's a very real possibility that there's no universally effective training for learning to fall. 

I find that on icy driveways I no longer am ashamed to grab onto door handles or whatever to have some form of support.

@Francis

One thing I learned from those in-services that DOES help is: when walking on ice, walk like a penguin. That is, smaller steps, side to side. My assistant and I always reminded each other when we left the building in the winter (this was in Wisconsin) "Walk like a penguin!" instead of "Have a good evening!" 

Thankfully, the pain from the frozen shoulder is now only a bad memory. My shoulder had to have its own pillow at night, and I have since learned that that is a normal thing for frozen shoulders! 

Were I to live my life over, it would include strength training and exercises to build up my body and be able to handle the inevitable aches and pains or the later years.

@Marlene

So glad to hear your pain has eased.

This might not be of much use to your, but my reading of Zen from Alan Watts suggests this:

When you feel pain, don't resist it.  Try to experience it as profoundly and deeply as you can.

That often makes the pain ease.  Sounds paradoxical, and I don't know if who it works for, or under what conditions, but the reality is that focussing on the pain doesn't intensify the pain.

My best.

P. S.  Boy, do you live in a lot of places!

@Francis My toes only go up and down; splaying them is something I don't know how to do. But living in Wisconsin, I've long since learned how to walk like a penguin and grab onto every handle I can find. I do some activities with the dogs at our local pound and some of them can really yank me around, so in the winter I frequently have to grab onto the chain link fencing just to stay upright between yards.
@Marlene Also there are these good pitons called Hillsound, I think. It‚Äôs a better Yak-Trax.

@Francis
I hope I'm not too late to get my toe in the door.  I have long toes (well, not  t h a t  long, but pretty long), and for as long as I can remember I have used them to pick things up off the floor, rearrange shoes to put them on, grip the shower floor, rake  something closer so I can lean over to pick it up, all sorts of things.  Once, in my doctor's office I handed myself something I had dropped, picking it up between my big and second toes my toes, and he said, You have prehensile toes?!!  Well, why not?  They have saved me from falling many times.  I can't use them to play a violin or type a letter, but within their limitations, they are my very useful friends.

@Francis 
I have seen more and more research that has emerged on the importance of building and maintaining toe strength for preserving and prolonging good balance as we age. In fact, my yoga classes now include toe strengthening positions. Even taking a small rolled up dishcloth and grasping it between your toes regularly can help strengthen them. There are a lot of reputable sites, including the NYT, that provide recommended toe exercises. Stay safe, especially during this slippery winter weather!

@Francis

Your post is still up so I guess either nobody flagged it as "off topic" or the moderators don't care. 

If you ever sprain a toe, you'll quickly realize how essential they are. 

Shall we talk about why puppies have wet noses now?

Somebody had to come in last, I guess.

@John Carson
I agree.  Not a very good clue.  How about ‚ÄúDevice providing ignition in an engine‚Äù?  Yes it helps start the engine, but then it keeps firing hundreds of times a minute to keep it running.

@Bruce and @John Carson

DHubby pointed out, "It won't start without gas, either, but the clue was still incorrect."

@Lewis

As do I, and you are a large part of why.

@solon
Good catch!  
I checked with my (erstwhile) Car Guy (now that everything is computerized, he can no longer do the repairs) and he agrees.  
The SPARK PLUGs keep the engine going, but to *START* the engine, one needs the SOLENOID (or a STARTER MOTOR, which wouldn't be an entry if a word is in the clue.)

@Mean Old Lady--Solenoid activates the Bendix which kick starts the starter which rotates the crankshaft which rotates all the other moving parts including (in older cars) the distributor rotor sending sequential electrical pulses to each spark plug igniting the fuel/air mixture which causes the pistons to push down onto the crankshaft and keep the engine running. And it all starts with the battery.
@Mean Old Lady  Ask your car guy what ignites the fuel AFTER a Diesel engine starts. It isn't the spark plug, it's compression of the fuel.

@SamBuddy
Where did the diesel engine come from?  We aren't driving semi's.

@solon

LITTLE CREATURES. 15 characters. Such a good catch! I guess the revealer having LITTLE may have thwarted its use, but I loved seeing your suggestion earlier today.

To Peter Gorman:

1) Print out two copies of this post from @Lewis,

2) Frame one and put it on your wall where everyone can see it,

3) Send the other to your mother. 

What a beautiful review. You can be very proud, Mr. Gorman.

@Rich in Atlanta Oh, and one more. A Monday from January 20, 1986 by Joy L. Wouk. Answers in that one: CORETTASCOTT IHAVEADREAM CIVILRIGHTS MARTINLUTHER Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/20/1986&g=52&d=A ...

@Rich in Atlanta

From back in the time when nobody complained about Wouk crossword puzzle constructors.
@Cherry I started with SiA before I realized it was SZA as well. I plugged in the ‚Äòi‚Äô without really reading the clue. It‚Äôs the newest KEA/LOA ü§£
@JohnW--But only one is a capital city, same with lots of Jacksons, but only one capital.

@Terri

Glad you asked!

As long as you conform to my personal crossword morality, no.

Kidding, we really don't enforce cheating rules here, other than "Have a good time".

@Terri welcome to the forum! Everyone has their own ‚Äúrules‚Äù for how they complete their puzzles. When I first started, I used the auto check feature. As I got better at them, I turned it off. I frequently looked up answers I didn‚Äôt know. I subscribed back in 2019. I now have a streak of unaided solves that started in July of 2021. It took two years to get to the point where I didn‚Äôt need to look up answers and I started remembering things from previous puzzles. My personal rule is that I can‚Äôt lookup any answer, but that is just my personal challenge to myself. I still look up answers I‚Äôm not familiar with after I complete the puzzle as I‚Äôm always interested in learning something new.

@Terri

The only person you are playing against is yourself, so you alone decide if it's frowned upon. For myself, I love crosswords because I learn something with almost every puzzle. And that means I usually have to look up something. It might be before I fill it in; it might be after. But it's your rule, and only yours.
@Terri solve em however you like!

@Terri Congratulations. Add me to the chorus who say, finish the puzzles in any way you can. I‚Äôve been doing the crossword for eight years (since I retired). I get that still makes me a relative noob, but I looked up and checked answers for a long while. Even now, there are weeks when I need to look up one or two to finish‚Ä¶but the only way to learn to solve is to solve.
@G training wheels is the perfect analogy!

@Terri,

So glad you asked this! This whole thread could be a primer for how you solve a crossword. Such good advice.

@Terri

I've been doing these for about a year. Use your own criteria, but when I sense that the puzzle is no longer fun for me, I turn on the autocheck, not really to check my monkey punching, but because so many clues have multiple correct answers. As a last resort, I start to look stuff up.  The only time I ever really get just angry is with the rebus, and I think there was one puzzle in 2025 that actually have numbers in it.

@Mean Old Lady

Box 41 almost has to be an S, since "for two" signals a plural (of whatever the named things might be)!

@Xword Junkie
I was not convinced...
AI what?
That was my question....

userLocation: Amdmt 25-not just a footnote any more
commentBody:
@Mean Old Lady
AIS. Plural of AI. The clue refers to two varieties of slop-producers.

@Kathryn I am not a sports expert whatsoever, but I do know that "traveling" is a basketball game violation that a ref would call -- when a player moves while holding the ball, rather than dribbling. I found it to be a clever little misdirect clue.
Yes Kelly, traveling is a violation, but the ref would NOT issue a warning, which the clue indicated.  So it was not a misdirect.  It   was wrong.

@Kathryn

Good point.

@Kathryn

...hit Submit too early...

It reminds me of the TV game show Jeopardy. Sometimes the contestants don't know a single answer in a sports category. 

But there will probably never be an error if the subject is table tennis since Mr. Shortz is an avid fan. üôÇ

Hi ad absurdum,

LOL, and of course, absurd!
@Suzanne Yes. So saying ‚ÄúUPC code‚Äù is redundant like saying ‚ÄúATM machine.‚Äù And yet‚Ä¶

commentBody:
@Jeremy
Do you really check every puzzle you do for pangrammitude? Really?? How long does it take for a Sunday puzzle? For the giganto-grid at the turn of the year?
@C  Bugged me, too.  I don't think it's a nitpick to say that one is just plain wrong.
@C   A diesel engine self-ignites the fuel after it starts, and the spark plug is not used after the engine starts. The clue is a misdirect but pretty accurate as written.

@SamBuddy - There are no spark plugs in diesels. There are glow plugs. 

No sparks needed!

@Remy Yes, there is a themed monthly bonus puzzle. I usually forget to go look for it. I don't know if there's an easy way to get to it from the app, but through your browser if you go to the crossword puzzle, then scroll down below all the other games, there is a row of crossword buttons, the monthly bonus and the last seven days' puzzles. https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords
@Kevin  Diesel engines start with a spark plug but continue running without one, so for a diesel engine it's more of a one-time action.
@SamBuddy - Diesels don't have spark plugs to get started -- they have glow plugs. No sparks involved!
